subject: RE: [junit] TestCase Dependency Hierarchy
msgSnippet: ... Not probably . Definitely. But probably NOT within my desired effort level. ;-) ... Maintaining test suites is not counterproductive if you have a need to
messageBody:
R.B Rainsberger wrote:

>As I said above, I know I *probably* could do it with suites ...

Not "probably". Definitely.

But probably NOT within my desired effort level. ;-)

>BUT. As I
>refactor, as code grows, the suites (being separate from the tests) are .
>but that seems a level of manual effort/management that is counter
>productive -- and hence counter testing. IMHO anything that can be better
>done by a computer ought be done by a computer.

Maintaining test suites is not counterproductive if you have a need to
maintain test suites. If you need to maintain test suites to do your work,
then maintaining test suites is, by definition, productive.

We are failing to communicate. Either I am wrong and stubbornly failing to
see your point (not impossible), or I am not explaining my issues w/ suites
well enough...

I agree that suites are a way to group tests and manage test group
hierarchy, however they aren't (IMHO) a good tool for managing test
hierarchies. Arrogant as that statement sounds, I honestly wonder if there
is "a better way" [for my use case, and hopefully for others]. I guess I
figure that if there is an easier way for developers to maintain test
dependencies, one that improves test results failure analysis, then testing
will be more effective/efficient. That seems nicely "test infecting" and
hence junit-like, to me.

Sure, I may be re-inventing the wheel -- and dumbly thinking I have
something new -- but I am attempting to pressure test that here. I'm making
one more step at explaining (see next reply to yours below). Please keep an
open mind to this as an optional addition/alternative to suites. If you just
can't see it, then so be it. I think the problem with the example I've given
are that they are too small & simple. Perhaps the difference can't be
explained by simple example.

If the method I am proposing makes sense for a decent chunk of the user
community, and makes junit more productive for that use case, then I see it
as a good alternative to test suites (which I feel are becoming obsolete by
test collectors). No reason why both couldn't be available.

I don't see how a computer can do what you're suggesting. If I
understood correctly, you want to identify tests that depend on one
another. What I suggested was a way to do that with what JUnit already
provides. Obviously, you can take that scheme, factor out a little engine
and make it data-driven; but my point remains: it's not an addition to JUnit
you seek, but another way of building suites.


I believe I am saying/seeing a different between a human maintaining
disjointed groupings (suites) and a human maintaining simple assertions of
dependency of a testcase on other testcases (or suites, I guess), and the
engine (runner) calculating the dependency order. I guess I am describing a
declarative mechanism (like ant) verses .. what would one call it ...
procedural?



>What suite would I create?

I would create the suite I know I need. But then, I don't view integration
tests by the objects they test: I view them by the features they support.


My examples were just simple ones. Dependency can be in the eye of the
beholder... :-)


>I would like to be able to set X to depend upon Y/Z (almost a "dynamic
>suite") and set A on Y and Z

If *you* are setting it, then how is that different from what I suggest?
Either a computer program determines the mapping, or you determine the
mapping. How you EXPRESS the mapping is just a matter of implementation
details. Start by maintaining the suite by hand, notice the patterns in the
way you do things, then script it.

Declarative verses "procedural".

Gak, why script it? That isn't going to fit into my eclipse, or ant tasks,
usage w/o some pain. Some things aren't worth doing unless they are accepted
by the core.


>Is what I am discussing unreasonable? It seems an easy interface for
users,
>and something that junit could manage behind the scenes.

I just don't think it's part of JUnit. It's a new Test Runner, perhaps.
It's a specialized Test Suite Builder. But the framework already supports
what you want; someone just has to do the work of building it.


Why not? Suites serve a purpose, why couldn't declarative. I agree, it means
changes to the runner, but maybe that is warranted in this age of
ant/eclipse test collectors...

regards

Adam
